Next generation JavaScript, today.

Turn ES6+ code into readable vanilla ES5 with source maps and more!

Introduction

ECMAScript 6 is the upcoming version of the ECMAScript standard. This standard is targeting ratification in June 2015. ES6 is a significant update to the language, and the first update to the language since ES5 was standardized in 2009. Implementation of these features in major JavaScript engines is underway now.

Get a tour of all the new features in ES6 →

Say Hello to 6to5.

6to5 turns ES6+ code into vanilla ES5, so you can use next generation features today.

Readable

Formatting is retained if possible so your generated code is as similar as possible.

class User extends Model {
  constructor() {
    super();
    this.sayHello();
  }

  sayHello() {
    alert("Hello World!");
  }
}
var User = function User() {
  Model.call(this);
  this.sayHello();
};

_extends(User, Model);

User.prototype.sayHello = function () {
  alert("Hello World!");
};

Extensible

With a large range of plugins and browser support.

Lossless

Source map support so you can debug your compiled code with ease.

Compact

Maps directly to the equivalent ES5 with no runtime.*

class User extends Model {
  constructor() {
    super();
    this.sayHello();
  }

  sayHello() {
    alert("Hello World!");
  }
}

var User = function User() {
  Model.call(this);
  this.sayHello();
};

_extends(User, Model);

User.prototype.sayHello = function () {
  alert("Hello World!");
};
Install 6to5

It's time to make the switch.

ES6 is available wherever you use JavaScript. So stop making excuses.

Browsers

6to5 has plugins for all of your favorite build systems. Check out the official plugins for Gulp, Grunt, Browserify, Webpack, Brocolli, and many more. You can also use the built-in CLI.

Node.js

Donec ullamcorper nulla non metus auctor fringilla. Vestibulum id ligula porta felis euismod semper. Praesent commodo cursus magna, vel scelerisque nisl consectetur. Fusce dapibus, tellus ac cursus commodo.

Rails

Sprockets 4 will ship with 6to5 by default using the .es6 file extension. Until then you can use the Sprockets ES6 transform or the official 6to5 Ruby Gem.

Browserify

6to5 and Browserify get along wonderfully with the official 6to5ify transform. 6to5 transforms the module syntax to browserify-compatible Common.js modules by default.
